canonical_explanation.text: Fluid mechanics deals with the behaviour of liquids and gases. Pressure in a fluid at depth h is P = P₀ + ρgh, where P₀ is atmospheric pressure. Pascal's law states that a pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished to every part of the fluid and the walls of the container. This is the basis of hydraulic machines: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. Archimedes' principle states that a body immersed in a fluid experiences a buoyant force equal to the weight of the displaced fluid: F_b = ρ_fluid × V_displaced × g. A body floats when its weight equals the buoyant force. For streamline (laminar) flow, the equation of continuity states A₁v₁ = A₂v₂ (conservation of mass). Bernoulli's theorem, based on energy conservation for ideal fluids, states P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant along a streamline. Applications include the venturimeter, atomiser, and the Magnus effect. Viscosity is the internal friction of a fluid. Newton's law of viscosity gives F = ηA(dv/dx), where η is the coefficient of viscosity. Stokes' law gives the drag force on a sphere: F = 6πηrv. The terminal velocity of a sphere falling through a viscous fluid is v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/9η. Surface tension (S) is the force per unit length along the surface of a liquid. Excess pressure inside a liquid drop is 2S/R, and inside a soap bubble is 4S/R. Capillary rise is h = 2S cosθ/(ρgr), where θ is the contact angle.
rules: Pressure at depth: P = P₀ + ρgh.
Pascal's law: pressure is transmitted equally in all directions in an enclosed fluid.
Archimedes' principle: buoyant force = weight of displaced fluid = ρ_fluid V_disp g.
Equation of continuity: A₁v₁ = A₂v₂ (for incompressible fluids).
Bernoulli's equation: P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant.
Stokes' law: F = 6πηrv; terminal velocity v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/(9η).

questions.question_text: The pressure at a depth h below the surface of a liquid of density ρ is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The absolute pressure at depth h is the sum of atmospheric pressure P₀ and the gauge pressure ρgh. This is P = P₀ + ρgh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ρgh is only the gauge pressure (pressure above atmospheric). The total (absolute) pressure includes atmospheric pressure P₀ acting on the surface.

questions.question_text: Pascal's law states that:

options.text: Pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid
Pressure in a fluid increases with depth
The buoyant force equals the weight of displaced fluid
The rate of flow of fluid is constant

questions.explanation_correct: Pascal's law states that pressure applied at any point on an enclosed fluid at rest is transmitted undiminished to every portion of the fluid and the walls of the container. This is the principle behind hydraulic machines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B describes pressure variation with depth (hydrostatic law). Option C is Archimedes' principle. Option D is the equation of continuity.

questions.question_text: In a hydraulic lift, the cross-sectional area of the small piston is 2 cm² and of the large piston is 200 cm². A force of 10 N is applied on the small piston. The force on the large piston is:
questions.explanation_correct: By Pascal's law: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. So F₂ = F₁ × A₂/A₁ = 10 × 200/2 = 1000 N. The hydraulic lift provides a mechanical advantage of 100.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pressure is transmitted equally: P = F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. The force multiplication factor is the ratio of areas: 200/2 = 100. So F₂ = 10 × 100 = 1000 N.

questions.question_text: A U-tube manometer contains mercury. If the difference in mercury levels in the two arms is 10 cm, the pressure difference between the two arms is (ρ_Hg = 13600 kg/m³, g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pressure difference is ΔP = ρ_mercury × g × h, where h must be in metres: h = 10 cm = 0.1 m. ΔP = 13600 × 10 × 0.1 = 13600 Pa.

questions.question_text: A liquid is kept in a sealed container. If the pressure at the bottom is P, and the atmospheric pressure is P₀, the height of the liquid column is (density ρ):
questions.explanation_correct: P = P₀ + ρgh at the bottom. Solving for h: h = (P − P₀)/(ρg). The height depends on the gauge pressure (P − P₀).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total pressure at the bottom P = P₀ + ρgh. Rearranging: h = (P − P₀)/(ρg). P/(ρg) would be correct only if P₀ = 0.

questions.question_text: According to Archimedes' principle, the buoyant force on a submerged body equals:

options.text: The weight of the fluid displaced by the body
The volume of the body times g
The pressure at the bottom of the body

questions.explanation_correct: Archimedes' principle states the buoyant force on a body immersed (fully or partially) in a fluid equals the weight of the fluid displaced: F_b = ρ_fluid × V_displaced × g.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force depends on the fluid's density and the volume displaced, not the body's weight. A body floats only when the buoyant force equals its weight.

questions.question_text: A body floats in water with 3/4 of its volume submerged. The relative density of the body is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a floating body: weight = buoyant force. ρ_body × V × g = ρ_water × (3V/4) × g. So ρ_body/ρ_water = 3/4 = 0.75. The relative density is 0.75.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fraction submerged equals the ratio of the body's density to the fluid's density. Since 3/4 is submerged: ρ_body/ρ_water = 3/4 = 0.75.

questions.question_text: A block of wood of density 600 kg/m³ and volume 0.02 m³ is floating in water. The volume of the block above the water surface is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fraction submerged = ρ_wood/ρ_water = 600/1000 = 0.6. Submerged volume = 0.6 × 0.02 = 0.012 m³. Volume above water = 0.02 − 0.012 = 0.008 m³.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since ρ_wood < ρ_water, the block floats with fraction submerged = 600/1000 = 60%. So 40% is above water: 0.4 × 0.02 = 0.008 m³.

questions.question_text: A body weighs 120 N in air and 80 N when fully immersed in water. The relative density of the body is:
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyant force = 120 − 80 = 40 N = weight of water displaced. Relative density = weight in air / loss of weight in water = 120/40 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The loss of weight in water equals the buoyant force: 120 − 80 = 40 N. Relative density = weight in air / buoyant force = 120/40 = 3.

questions.question_text: An ice cube floats in water. When the ice completely melts, the water level:
questions.explanation_correct: While floating, the ice displaces a volume of water equal to its own weight. When it melts, it produces exactly that volume of water. Therefore, the water level remains unchanged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By Archimedes' principle, the floating ice displaces water equal to its own weight. The meltwater has exactly this weight and volume (since both are water). Hence, no change in level.

questions.question_text: The equation of continuity for fluid flow is based on the conservation of:
questions.explanation_correct: The equation of continuity A₁v₁ = A₂v₂ is a statement of conservation of mass for an incompressible fluid. The mass flowing per unit time must be the same at every cross-section.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bernoulli's equation is based on energy conservation. The equation of continuity (Av = constant) follows from mass conservation: the mass flow rate ρAv must be constant along a streamline.

questions.question_text: Bernoulli's theorem is essentially a statement of conservation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Bernoulli's equation P + ½ρv² + ρgh = constant is the energy conservation principle applied per unit volume of an ideal (non-viscous, incompressible) fluid: pressure energy + kinetic energy + potential energy = constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each term in Bernoulli's equation has dimensions of energy per unit volume (Pa = J/m³). P is pressure energy, ½ρv² is KE, and ρgh is PE, all per unit volume.

questions.question_text: Water flows through a horizontal pipe of varying cross-section. At a point where the speed is 2 m/s, the pressure is 1.5 × 10⁵ Pa. At another point where the speed is 5 m/s, the pressure is (ρ = 1000 kg/m³):
questions.explanation_correct: By Bernoulli's equation (horizontal pipe, so h is same): P₁ + ½ρv₁² = P₂ + ½ρv₂². P₂ = P₁ + ½ρ(v₁² − v₂²) = 1.5 × 10⁵ + ½ × 1000 × (4 − 25) = 1.5 × 10⁵ − 10500 = 1.395 × 10⁵ Pa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Where speed increases, pressure decreases (Bernoulli's effect). P₂ = 1.5×10⁵ + ½(1000)(4 − 25) = 150000 − 10500 = 139500 Pa = 1.395 × 10⁵ Pa.

questions.question_text: Water flows through a pipe with a cross-sectional area of 10 cm² at a speed of 5 m/s. If the pipe narrows to 5 cm², the speed of water is:
questions.explanation_correct: By equation of continuity: A₁v₁ = A₂v₂. v₂ = A₁v₁/A₂ = (10 × 5)/5 = 10 m/s. When the pipe narrows, the fluid speeds up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equation of continuity (Av = constant) gives v₂ = (A₁/A₂)v₁ = (10/5) × 5 = 10 m/s.

questions.question_text: A tank is filled with water to a height H. A small hole is made at a depth h below the surface. The velocity of efflux of water from the hole is:
questions.explanation_correct: By Torricelli's theorem (a special case of Bernoulli's equation), the speed of efflux from a hole at depth h below the surface is v = √(2gh), the same as the speed of a body falling freely through height h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Torricelli's theorem states that the efflux velocity depends on the depth of the hole below the surface (h), not the total height of the tank. v = √(2gh).

questions.question_text: The viscous drag force on a sphere of radius r moving with velocity v through a fluid of viscosity η is given by Stokes' law as:
questions.explanation_correct: Stokes' law states that the viscous drag force on a sphere is F = 6πηrv, where η is the viscosity, r is the radius, and v is the velocity. It is valid for small Reynolds numbers (laminar flow).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stokes' law: F = 6πηrv. The force depends on the first power of both r and v. The coefficient 6π comes from the mathematical solution of the Navier-Stokes equations for a sphere.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of coefficient of viscosity is:
questions.explanation_correct: From F = ηA(dv/dx), η = F/(A × dv/dx) = N/(m² × s⁻¹) = N·s/m² = Pa·s. The CGS unit poise = 0.1 Pa·s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The SI unit of viscosity is Pa·s (or equivalently N·s/m² or kg/(m·s)). 1 Pa·s = 10 poise.

questions.question_text: The terminal velocity of a sphere falling through a viscous fluid is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: Terminal velocity v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/(9η). It is proportional to r². A sphere with double the radius has 4 times the terminal velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/(9η), terminal velocity depends on r², η, (ρ − σ), and g. It varies as the square of the radius.

questions.question_text: Two spheres of the same material but radii r and 2r fall through a viscous liquid. The ratio of their terminal velocities is:
questions.explanation_correct: v_t ∝ r² (same material means same ρ). So v₁/v₂ = r²/(2r)² = 1/4. The ratio is 1 : 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terminal velocity v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/(9η) ∝ r² for same material and fluid. With radii r and 2r: v₁ : v₂ = r² : 4r² = 1 : 4.

questions.question_text: A sphere of density 2000 kg/m³ and radius 0.01 m falls through a fluid of density 800 kg/m³ and viscosity 0.5 Pa·s. The terminal velocity is approximately (g = 10 m/s²):
Surface tension is defined as:

options.text: Force per unit length acting along the surface of a liquid
Force per unit area acting on the surface
Energy per unit volume of the liquid

questions.explanation_correct: Surface tension S is defined as the force per unit length acting in the plane of the surface and perpendicular to any line drawn on the surface. Its SI unit is N/m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force per unit area is pressure, not surface tension. Surface tension acts along the surface (tangentially), not perpendicular to it like pressure. Its unit is N/m.

questions.question_text: The excess pressure inside a soap bubble of radius R and surface tension S is:
questions.explanation_correct: A soap bubble has two surfaces (inner and outer). Each contributes an excess pressure of 2S/R. Total excess pressure = 4S/R. For a liquid drop (single surface), it is 2S/R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A liquid drop has one surface (excess pressure = 2S/R), but a soap bubble has two surfaces. So the excess pressure for a soap bubble is 4S/R.

questions.question_text: Water rises to a height of 10 cm in a capillary tube. If a tube of half the radius is used, water will rise to:
questions.explanation_correct: Capillary rise h = 2S cosθ/(ρgr). Since h ∝ 1/r, halving the radius doubles the height: h' = 2 × 10 = 20 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From h = 2S cosθ/(ρgr), height is inversely proportional to radius. If r → r/2, then h → 2h = 20 cm.

questions.question_text: The angle of contact for mercury in a glass tube is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mercury does not wet glass, so the meniscus is convex and the angle of contact is obtuse (about 140°). This is why mercury shows capillary depression in glass tubes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water wets glass (acute angle, about 0°), but mercury does not wet glass (obtuse angle, about 140°). This determines whether the liquid rises or falls in a capillary tube.

questions.question_text: Two soap bubbles of radii r₁ and r₂ (r₁ > r₂) are connected by a tube. Air will flow:

options.text: From the smaller bubble to the larger bubble
From the larger bubble to the smaller bubble

questions.explanation_correct: Excess pressure inside a bubble = 4S/R. The smaller bubble (r₂) has higher internal pressure (4S/r₂ > 4S/r₁). Air flows from higher to lower pressure, i.e., from the smaller to the larger bubble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since excess pressure ∝ 1/R, the smaller bubble has higher pressure inside. Air flows from high to low pressure: from the small bubble to the large one. The small bubble shrinks and the large one grows.

questions.question_text: In a venturimeter, the fluid pressure is lowest at the:
questions.explanation_correct: By Bernoulli's principle, where the fluid speed is highest (narrow section), the pressure is lowest. By the equation of continuity, the speed is highest at the narrowest section.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equation of continuity (Av = constant) gives maximum speed at the throat. Bernoulli's equation then gives minimum pressure at the throat.

questions.question_text: An aeroplane wing is designed so that air moves faster over the top surface than the bottom. This creates lift because:

options.text: The pressure above the wing is lower than below (Bernoulli's principle)
The pressure above the wing is higher than below
Air pushes the wing from below due to Newton's third law only
The weight of air above decreases with altitude

questions.explanation_correct: By Bernoulli's principle, higher speed above the wing means lower pressure above. The pressure difference (higher below, lower above) creates a net upward force (lift).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bernoulli's principle: where fluid velocity is higher, pressure is lower. The wing's shape forces air to move faster over the top, reducing pressure there and creating upward lift.

questions.question_text: A liquid of density ρ is placed in a container on a weighing scale. A solid block of mass m and density 2ρ is lowered into the liquid by a string until fully immersed. The reading on the scale:
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force on the block = ρ(m/2ρ)g = mg/2. By Newton's third law, the block pushes the liquid down with force mg/2. The scale reading increases by mg/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The block displaces liquid of volume V = m/(2ρ). The buoyant force on the block is ρVg = ρ × m/(2ρ) × g = mg/2. By Newton's third law, this force acts on the liquid (and hence the scale), increasing the reading by mg/2.

questions.question_text: At terminal velocity, the net force on a body falling through a viscous fluid is:

options.text: Equal to the weight of the body

questions.explanation_correct: At terminal velocity, the body moves with constant velocity, so the net force is zero. Weight = drag force + buoyant force. The three forces are in equilibrium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terminal velocity means zero acceleration, which requires zero net force. This occurs when mg = 6πηrv_t + ρ_fluid × V × g (weight = drag + buoyancy).

questions.question_text: The work done in blowing a soap bubble from radius r to radius 2r (surface tension = S) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Work = S × change in total surface area. A soap bubble has two surfaces. Total area change = 2[4π(2r)² − 4π(r²)] = 2 × 4π × 3r² = 24πr². Work = S × 24πr² = 24πr²S.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A soap bubble has inner and outer surfaces. Total surface area = 2 × 4πr². Change = 2[4π(2r)² − 4πr²] = 2 × 4π(4r² − r²) = 24πr². Work = 24πr²S.

questions.question_text: Two liquids of densities ρ₁ and ρ₂ are poured into a U-tube and reach equilibrium. If the height of liquid 1 is h₁ and of liquid 2 is h₂ above the interface, then:
questions.explanation_correct: At the interface (same horizontal level), the pressure from both sides must be equal: P₀ + ρ₁gh₁ = P₀ + ρ₂gh₂, giving ρ₁h₁ = ρ₂h₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a U-tube at equilibrium, the pressure at the same level must be equal. Equating pressures at the liquid interface: ρ₁gh₁ = ρ₂gh₂, hence ρ₁h₁ = ρ₂h₂.

questions.question_text: Bernoulli's equation is applicable to:

options.text: Streamline flow of an ideal (non-viscous, incompressible) fluid
Viscous flow of a real fluid
Compressible gas flow at high speeds

questions.explanation_correct: Bernoulli's equation applies to steady (streamline), non-viscous, incompressible fluid flow along a streamline. It is derived from the work-energy theorem for ideal fluids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bernoulli's equation is an idealisation valid for non-viscous, incompressible, steady flow. It fails for turbulent flow, viscous fluids, and compressible gases at high speeds.

questions.question_text: The excess pressure inside a spherical liquid drop of radius R and surface tension S is:
questions.explanation_correct: A liquid drop has only one surface (unlike a soap bubble which has two). The excess pressure inside a liquid drop is ΔP = 2S/R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a liquid drop (one surface): ΔP = 2S/R. For a soap bubble (two surfaces): ΔP = 4S/R. This distinction is important.

questions.question_text: A solid sphere of density ρ/2 is released from the bottom of a liquid of density ρ. The acceleration of the sphere as it rises is:
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyant force = ρVg (upward). Weight = (ρ/2)Vg (downward). Net upward force = ρVg − (ρ/2)Vg = (ρ/2)Vg. Acceleration = net force/mass = (ρ/2)Vg / [(ρ/2)V] = g (upward).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Net upward force = buoyancy − weight = ρVg − (ρ/2)Vg = (ρ/2)Vg. Mass of sphere = (ρ/2)V. So a = F/m = g upward.

questions.question_text: If the radius of a sphere falling through a viscous medium is doubled (same material), its terminal velocity becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: v_t = 2r²(ρ − σ)g/(9η) ∝ r². Doubling the radius: v_t' = (2r)² × k = 4r²k = 4v_t.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terminal velocity is proportional to r². Doubling r gives v_t' = 4v_t.

questions.question_text: The height to which water rises in a capillary tube of radius 0.2 mm is (S = 0.072 N/m, contact angle = 0°, ρ = 1000 kg/m³, g = 10 m/s²):
The Magnus effect is observed when a spinning ball curves in flight. This is explained by:

options.text: Bernoulli's principle: unequal air speeds on opposite sides create a pressure difference

questions.explanation_correct: A spinning ball drags air along with it, making air move faster on one side (where spin and airflow are in the same direction) and slower on the other. By Bernoulli's principle, the fast side has lower pressure, causing the ball to curve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Magnus effect is a direct consequence of Bernoulli's principle. The spin creates asymmetric airflow speeds, leading to a pressure difference and hence a lateral force.

questions.question_text: The atmospheric pressure at sea level is approximately equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: Standard atmospheric pressure = 1.013 × 10⁵ Pa = 101.3 kPa = 760 mm Hg = 1 atm. This is the pressure exerted by a column of air reaching to the top of the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1 atm = 1.013 × 10⁵ Pa. This is equivalent to the pressure of a 760 mm mercury column.

questions.question_text: Rain drops reach the ground with a finite velocity instead of a very large velocity because of:

options.text: Air resistance (viscous drag) — they reach terminal velocity
The gravitational force decreases with altitude
The buoyant force of air exceeds their weight

questions.explanation_correct: As raindrops fall, the viscous drag of air increases with speed until it equals the net downward force (weight minus buoyancy). At this point, they reach terminal velocity and fall at constant speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Without air resistance, raindrops would accelerate continuously and hit the ground at dangerous speeds. The viscous drag of air limits their speed to terminal velocity.

questions.question_text: Surface tension of a liquid generally:
questions.explanation_correct: Surface tension decreases with increasing temperature because higher thermal energy weakens the intermolecular cohesive forces at the surface. At the critical temperature, surface tension becomes zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher temperature increases molecular kinetic energy, reducing the effective cohesive forces between surface molecules. This decreases surface tension.

questions.question_text: A body of density ρ₁ is dropped into a fluid of density ρ₂ (where ρ₁ > ρ₂). The apparent weight of the body in the fluid is:
questions.explanation_correct: Apparent weight = actual weight − buoyant force = Vρ₁g − Vρ₂g = Vg(ρ₁ − ρ₂).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force equals the weight of fluid displaced: Vρ₂g. Apparent weight = true weight − buoyancy = Vρ₁g − Vρ₂g = Vg(ρ₁ − ρ₂).

questions.question_text: A hydraulic press has pistons of areas 1 cm² and 100 cm². To lift a car of weight 10,000 N, the force applied on the smaller piston should be at least:
questions.explanation_correct: F₁/A₁ = F₂/A₂. F₁ = F₂ × A₁/A₂ = 10000 × 1/100 = 100 N. The mechanical advantage is 100.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By Pascal's law: F₁ = F₂ × (A₁/A₂) = 10000 × (1/100) = 100 N.

questions.question_text: Water flows through a horizontal tube with a constriction. The ratio of the areas of the wider and narrower sections is 3:1. If the velocity in the wider section is 2 m/s, the velocity in the narrower section is:
questions.explanation_correct: By continuity equation: A₁v₁ = A₂v₂. v₂ = (A₁/A₂) × v₁ = 3 × 2 = 6 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since area decreases by factor 3, velocity must increase by factor 3 (conservation of mass): v₂ = 3 × 2 = 6 m/s.

questions.question_text: If a capillary tube is dipped in water and the tube is tilted from vertical at angle θ, the length of the water column in the tube:
questions.explanation_correct: The vertical height of the water column remains h (determined by the balance of surface tension and weight). But the length along the tilted tube increases to h/cosθ, since the vertical component of the column length must still equal h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The vertical height is fixed at h = 2Scosθ_c/(ρgr). When tilted at angle θ, the liquid column length increases to l = h/cosθ to maintain the same vertical height.

questions.question_text: The viscosity of an ideal fluid is:
questions.explanation_correct: An ideal (or perfect) fluid has zero viscosity and is incompressible. It is an idealisation used in deriving Bernoulli's equation and the equation of continuity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, an ideal fluid is non-viscous (zero viscosity) and incompressible. Real fluids always have some viscosity.

questions.question_text: A submarine sinks in water by:

options.text: Filling its ballast tanks with water to increase its average density

questions.explanation_correct: A submarine controls its buoyancy by flooding or emptying ballast tanks. When water enters the tanks, the average density increases beyond that of seawater, making it sink.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Submarines use ballast tanks to control their average density relative to seawater. When ρ_sub > ρ_water, it sinks. When ρ_sub < ρ_water, it floats.

questions.question_text: The energy needed to form a liquid drop of radius R and surface tension S is:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy needed equals surface energy = surface tension × surface area = S × 4πR². A liquid drop has one surface with area 4πR².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Surface energy = S × area. A liquid drop has one surface of area 4πR². So energy = 4πR²S. (A soap bubble would have 8πR²S due to two surfaces.)

questions.question_text: Water is flowing through a horizontal pipe. If a hole is made on the top of the pipe, water:

options.text: Will rise to a height depending on the speed of flow and the pressure at that point
Will not come out at all
Will always rise to the same height regardless of flow speed

questions.explanation_correct: By Bernoulli's principle, the pressure in the pipe depends on the flow speed. If the pressure exceeds atmospheric, water rises to a height h where P_pipe = P₀ + ρgh. The height depends on the fluid's speed and pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The height to which water rises from a hole on top of a pipe depends on the gauge pressure at that point. By Bernoulli's equation, this pressure depends on both the static pressure and the fluid velocity.

questions.question_text: The pressure at the bottom of a lake of depth 10 m is (P₀ = 1.013 × 10⁵ Pa, ρ = 1000 kg/m³, g = 9.8 m/s²):
questions.explanation_incorrect: Total pressure = atmospheric + gauge pressure = 1.013 × 10⁵ + (1000 × 9.8 × 10) = 1.013 × 10⁵ + 0.98 × 10⁵ = 1.993 × 10⁵ Pa.

questions.question_text: A capillary tube of insufficient length (shorter than the expected rise height h) is dipped in water. What happens?

options.text: Water rises to the top but does not overflow; the meniscus adjusts its radius of curvature
Water overflows from the top of the capillary
Water does not rise at all
Water rises to h and then falls back

questions.explanation_correct: Water rises to the top of the tube but does not overflow. The meniscus adjusts to a larger radius of curvature to reduce the excess pressure to match the shorter column. Since h = 2Scosθ/(ρgr), if h is limited, the effective r of the meniscus increases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a tube shorter than h, water cannot overflow (that would violate energy conservation). Instead, the meniscus at the top adjusts its curvature — it becomes flatter (larger R) so that the reduced capillary pressure balances the shorter water column.
